intro: Pseudocaryophyllus sericeus, commonly known as the silky sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the family Aizoaceae, commonly referred to as the ice plant family, and is characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves and small, star-shaped flowers. The plant has a low-growing, sprawling habit and produces a profusion of pale pink to white flowers during the cooler months. Its hairy, silky leaves are adapted to reduce water loss in hot, dry environments, making it well-suited for xerophytic conditions. Pseudocaryophyllus sericeus is often used in rock gardens and as an ornamental plant due to its unique appearance and drought tolerance.
